name: Black Down (Dorset)
description: Modern Stone Circle etc in Dorset. "The Black Down stone circle consists of five totems built from local Forest Marble stone. One is aligned with true north and the other four with the midwinter and midsummer solstice sunrises and sunsets. In clear conditions at each of these times, the Suns full disc shines through an opening in one of the totems, lighting up a central rock of Portland stone."

name: Monkton-up-Wimborne Late Neolithic pit circle/shaft complex
description: Excavated in 1997 by Martin Green, the Monkton Up Wimborne site in Dorset is unique and comprises a large central pit surrounded by a ring of smaller pits. To one side of this pit is the burial of a Middle Neolithic family: a mother and several children, dating to c.3500 BC. Close to this burial a shaft 7m deep was dug into the chalk.

name: Mount Pleasant (Dorset)
description: Henge, Barrows and Timber circle in Dorset. Conquer Barrow sits in the extreme west side of the field containing Mount Pleasant henge and overlies the henge earthworks on the western side. Quoting Martyn Barber, Historic England Aerial survey: "Three barrows were already known - the massive Conquer Barrow, which either sits on the henge's western bank or was already standing and incorporated within the henge bank when the latter was built, is the most obvious. The remains of two more normally proportioned mounds lie to the south-east of the henge."

name: Valley of Stones circle
description: Possible large stone circle in the south-easterly section of the Valley of Stones in Dorset. Gerald Ponting writes: When I went down there I became convinced that this was a genuine megalithic circle. As far as I know, there seems no record of this as an archaeological site - unless you know better.

name: Rempstone
description: A forgotten gem of a site, nestled in the enclosing bosom of the Purbeck Hills, Dorset. A once grand circle and remains of stone avenues, now almost forgotten. Really atmospheric despite it's near destruction and roadside proximity.

name: Knowlton Rings
description: Henge in Dorset with a church built in the middle, which must point to early Christianisation of a pagan temple. There are actually three henges here, as shown in detailed research done by students of Bournemouth University.

name: Hengistbury Head
description: Evidence of a very long period of occupation with evidence of palaeolithic and mesolithic hunters, 13 Bronze Age barrows and an Iron Age promontory fort in Dorset. Numerous finds particularly from the period after 7th century BC when the area became a major port trading with Gaul and the Mediterranean.

name: Bronkham Hill
description: A multitude of round barrows on Bronkham Hill in Dorset, part of the Dorset Ridgeway. The barrows are scattered along the length of the ridge, with an incredible density.

name: St Candida & Holy Cross (Whitchurch Canonicorum)
description: Early Christian Sculptured Stone in Dorset

name: Hellstone
description: Long Barrow in Dorset. The Hellstone on Portesham Hill is an impressive dolmen, restored in 1866 after the capstone had fallen some six years earlier.

name: Church Hill Enclosure (Alton Pancras)
description: A square earthwork, about 25m each side, a raised bank about 1m above the flat surrounding ground, immediately adjacent to the Wessex Ridgeway, not far from the famous crossroads of ancient Wessex trackways called the Dorset Gap.

name: Bindon Hill Barrows
description: Near the eastern end of the Bindon Hill ridge, just away from the actual summit, are the ruined remains of a couple of barrows.

name: Hambury Tout Barrows
description: There are a couple of barrows on top of Hambury Tout, near the busy coast path on top of the steep hill between Lulworth Cove and Durdle Dor.

name: Maiden Castle (Dorset)
description: Neolithic Causewayed Enclosure and Iron Age Hillfort in Dorset. The most spectacular hillfort in southern England.

name: Tout Quarry Sculpture Park - The Circle of Stones
description: Tout Quarry is a disused quarry that has been a nature reserve and sculpture park since 1983 with the formation of the Portland Sculpture and Quarry Trust [1]. The quarry is home to a collection of amazing sculptures, one of which is the The Circle of Stones or Cirkel van Stenen in the language of the sculptors.

name: Tout Quarry Sculpture Park Stone Circle
description: This modern stone circle (more of a 'cove' of stones, I suggest) at Portland's Tout Quarry Sculpture Park on Portland Bill in Dorset was officially opened on June 21st 2017. Also a modern stone row (see nearby sites).

name: Tout Quarry Sculpture Park Alignment
description: A modern megalithic alignment on a ridge on the north west side of Tout Quarry Sculpture Park.

name: Wor Barrow
description: Long Barrow in Dorset, seemingly the first scientifically excavated long barrow. The barrow was totally excavated in 1893-4 by General Pitt-Rivers in one of the earliest systematic archaeological digs. The barrow was oval in shape with completely surrounding ditches, 45m long and 23m wide and 6m high, aligned along a NE-SW axis.

name: Knowle Hill Farm long barrow
description: Excavations at Knowlton, run by the University of Southampton, are investigating a possible Neolithic long barrow or mortuary enclosure located around 500m from the

name: Culverwell Mesolithic Site
description: Mesolithic Settlement on Portland Bill in Dorset. The main feature on this site is a large floor of limestone slabs on top of a shell midden (rubbish dump). This floor is the earliest known structural evidence in England for the extensive use of Portland Jurassic limestone on a living site.

name: St Dunstan's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Dorset

name: Eggardon Hill
description: One of the best hillforts in Dorset. Some complain that the problem with hillforts is that they are on hills! Eggardon Hill is minimum effort, maximum reward, and is best approached on the promontory from the east, having come along the line of the Roman Road.

name: Maumbury Rings
description: Excavations between 1908 and 1913 indicated this site's origin to be a Neolithic henge. There was a wide ditch inside the circular bank, with a series of tapering shafts about 3 metres apart (suggesting 45 in total). Excavation of eight of the shafts revealed that they were deliberately filled, some containing red deer skulls (or skull fragments) and carved chalk objects.

name: Badbury Rings
description: Hillfort in Dorset. Three well-worn chalk banks and ditches surround 7 hectares of trees inside. This Iron Age hillfort has never been excavated, so details are sketchy at best, although it lies at the junction of two Roman roads.

name: Dorset Cursus
description: The Dorset Cursus, probably Britain's largest neolithic site, runs for 6 miles (10km) through the chalk downs of Cranborne Chase. Originally it consisted of a pair of parallel banks about 90m apart running northeast-southwest, but not perfectly straight. It is now largely visible only as crop or soil marks, but some of the original earthworks remain along with many associated long barrows.

name: Cerne Abbas Giant
description: Hill Figure in Dorset. The Cerne Abbas Giant is a hill-figure cut into the turf and underlying bedrock to expose a white chalk outline. He is almost 60 metres tall, and brandishes a club 36 metres long. His body is outlined and detailed by narrow trenches no more than 0.6 metres wide, and his condition has been maintained by periodic scouring by local people - an activity traditionally separated by long intervals.

name: Long Bredy Bank Barrow
description: A Neolithic bank barrow on Martin's Down oriented NE-SW, 195m long and 20m wide with parallel ditches either side. After the unusually long

name: Wyke Down henge
description: Two Henges in Dorset, excavated in 1983-4 and 1996. Although they were constructed as a series of pits, the causeways between the pits are very low, indicating that it was a continuous ditch rather than a series of separate pits.

name: The Ancient Technology Centre
description: The ATC began over 25 years ago as a school project with the building of an Iron Age roundhouse based on archaeological evidence. It now has six full sized reconstructions of ancient buildings.

name: Kingston Russell Barrow
description: Only a few hundred yards from Kingston Russell Stone circle lies this lovely round barrow, it has some slight erosion on the sides but stands a good 3 Meters high.

name: Valley of Stones quarry
description: A quarry for the stones used in the several megalithic sites within about 5 miles of the valley. The Valley of Stones has been a National Nature Reserve since 1999. The English Nature noticeboard on site mentions that, as well as all the stones which are haphazardly arranged due to a geological event, some of them are arranged as a circle.

name: Ringmoor Settlement
description: Ancient Settlement in Dorset. Ringmoor Settlement, Turnworth, Dorset is an ancient settlement or farmstead on the side of Bulbarrow Hill. It is located on a bridleway and the site is owned by the National Trust. It has not been greatly excavated but is usually described as Iron Age and occupied by the Durotriges. It is about 130 acres in extent, there is a pond at the top, a banked track leading to a circular banked enclosure, and a number of field enclosures also indicated by banks.

name: Clandon Barrow
description: Round Barrow in Dorset. This barrow produced some very interesting finds, including a shale macehead with gold bosses, and a gold lozenge with a similar pattern to the famous one found in Bush Barrow.

name: Herringston Long Barrow
description: Long Barrow in Dorset. A mutilated mound of over 60 m length which is partly crossed by a field boundary. Although this mound and the nearby bowl barrow are often referred to as one site called Herringston Barrrow, they are two different monuments. The long mound is probably a Neolithic long barrow.

name: Jacob's Well (Portland)
description: This is a lovely spring lying just off a rough footpath leading south from Chesil Cove along the West Weares - listen out for the sound of water trickling left of the path. The water pours from beneath large boulders.

name: St Catherine's Hill (Christchurch)
description: St Catherine's Hill is a 35 hectare area of heathland and coniferous forest. It is the highest area of Christchurch and has most likely been used as a look-out and beacon since prehistoric times due to its commanding views of the surrounding area. Eleven tumuli or barrows surround the ridges as monuments to the succeeding Bronze age settlers and Iron Age farmers may have built the enclosure just to the south west of the radio mast.

name: St John's Well (Evershot)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Dorset

name: Ashley Heath North
description: Round Barrow in Dorset, the most impressive of 5 local barrows. They are too loosely associated perhaps to be called a barrow cemetery, and occupy scarps that look both north west and south west. All are damaged by forestry work and each has a central depression from being dug out at some time in the past.

name: Golden Cap Barrows
description: There are five Bronze Age burial mounds visible on the summit of Golden Cap, the highest point of the coast path through Dorset at 191m (626ft) above sea level.

name: Dorset County Museum
description: Museum in Dorset. Prehistoric tools, displays on Maiden Castle, Maumbury. Mount Pleasant and other locations.

name: Boveridge Heath
description: Boveridge Heath (which is the northern end of Ringwood Forest) has a good many tumuli but most are sadly in an atrocious condition, largely due to forestry work. Some have been quite levelled to the ground, their only indication of presence being monument 'M' marker posts in each corner, as indeed they all have. If this is the only good thing to have come out of the operations then it is good indeed, as the levelling has otherwise diminished the sites to near invisibility in the scrub.

name: Dudsbury Camp
description: Hillfort in Dorset. This is a form of promontory hillfort which is above a bend in the river Stour. The most substantial earthworks are two sets of banks and ditches north of the interior. These are visible from the public footpath but are on private land.

name: Double Dykes Bowl Barrow
description: Bronze age bowl barrow in Dorset

name: Hambledon Hill hillfort
description: Iron Age Hillfort in Dorset. One of the best hillforts in Britain.

name: The Ulwell Barrow
description: A round barrow on the Ballard Down ridge, similar to others on the ridge except that this one has an obelisk erected on its southern side.

name: Doghouse Hill
description:
Ancient Settlement in Dorset. Archaeologists working for the National Trust think they have found West Dorset's oldest human settlement.
Excavations over the last two weeks began when a number of artefacts were found by a man walking his dog.

name: Three Barrows (Furzebrook)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Dorset. Three barrows fenced off from nearby farmland with a telephone pole planted smack in the middle of them. Rabbits have dug into them but not disastrously so.

name: The Bearstone
description:
We managed to get this fine limestone monolith raised on the 7th Aug 2008. We found it fallen and under vegetation, excavated, measured it and calculated the weight (about 1,000 kg). 
It has a flat bottom and pointed apex, like a thick triangle, sits very comfortably. The county archeologist came to see it and gave me permission to lift it.

name: High Lea Farm
description:
Barrow Cemetery in Dorset 
This group comprises a barrow cemetery composed of round barrows and oval barrows. Only a small number of the barrows are visible as earthworks, the remainder are visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. [

name: Swyre Head
description: This bowl barrow is the highest point in the Isle of Purbeck, on Swyre Head (not to be confused with the other Dorset Swyre Head on the coast to the west of Durdle Door). On a clear day there are fantastic views for many miles in all directions.

name: The King Barrow (Isle of Purbeck)
description: Bowl barrow 16 metres in diameter and up to 1 metre high.

name: St. Edward the Martyr's Well
description: Within the ruins of Corfe Castle is a deep impression said to be the location of the well where the body of the murdered Saxon king was thrown down in 978 before the Castle was built.

name: Leper's Well (Lyme Regis)
description: This interesting site tucked away in a public park behind the main street is believed associated with a leper hospital although its waters were said to be efficiacous with other complaints and considered holy.

name: Four Barrow Hill
description: According the great L.V.Grinsell this is the only examle of a quadruple barrow in the British Isles.

name: Nine Stones (Dorset)
description: This small circle has some huge stones and some tiny ones, ranging from 90cm to 3.4m. Trees have grown up around the circle almost obscuring it, giving a dark, melancholy air.

name: Rainbarrows
description:
Round Barrows in Dorset.

The Rainbarrows are three bowl barrows at the top of Duddle Heath on the edge of Puddletown Forest. They were partly excavated by Edward Cunnington in 1887 and the discovered urns containing cremations are now in the Dorset County Museum.

name: Eggardon earthwork
description: Circular earthwork in Dorset - interpreted as either a henge or disc barrow.

name: Southdown (Dorset)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Dorset. Another Dorset Bronze Age barrow cemetery in a chalk-ridge setting, akin to the nearby

name: St Mary's Well (Hermitage)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Dorset

name: Afflington Barrow
description: The Afflington Barrow is a bronze age bowl barrow about 22 metres in diameter and nearly 2 metres in height. Its surrounding ditch has become infilled.

name: Agglestone
description: Natural Stone / Glacial Erratic in Dorset

name: Puckstone
description: Natural Stone / Glacial Erratic in Dorset

name: Studland
description: A stone row of at least 6 stones, but most very difficult to find.

name: Maiden Castle Barrow Cemetery
description: This Bronze Age barrow cemetery, located about 500m north of Maiden Castle, is grouped around the site of a neolithic long barrow which has long since been ploughed flat.

name: Caesar's Camp (Dorset)
description: Caesar's Camp is a univallate Iron Age hill fort crowning Bussey Down before it slopes steeply to the west; the eastern slope is less severe. It takes its name no doubt from its close proximity to the Badbury Rings - Bath, Roman road ( Margary 46 ) which also crosses Bussey Down to the west of the site.

name: Holdenhurst Long Barrow
description: Destroyed earthen long barrow in Dorset

name: Maiden Castle Bank Barrow
description: Britain's longest long barrow, uniquely long at 546 metres, running over the neolithic causewayed camp on top of Maiden Castle. The details of its structure suggest that it was originally a more conventional long barrow that was extended in both directions.

name: Grove Road
description: Possible Stone Circle in Dorset. On a

name: Gussage Down (South)
description: Long Barrow in Dorset. This neolithic earthern barrow is 64m long and about 14m in breadth at its widest point.

name: Gussage Down (North)
description: Long Barrow in Hampshire. This well-proportioned neolithic earthern barrow, trapezoidal in plan, is 50m long and about 25m in breadth at its widest point. As with many of the long barrows in this region its long axis points SE-NW, with the wider flatter end to the SE. It stands atop the ridge of Gussage Down and is visible for many miles around, and would have been intervisible with many other long barrows during neolithic times. Its parallel ditches have silted up but the mound itself is in good condition (with some modern agricultural debris at its lower NW end).

name: Northdown (Dorset)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Dorset. Another Dorset Bronze Age barrow cemetery in a spectacular chalk-ridge setting, akin to the nearby

name: Nettlecombe Tout
description: This Iron Age fort is located on the end of a spur called Nettlecombe Tout. It is protected by very steep hillsides to the north-west and north-east, and the spur is cut across at the south-east by a bank and ditch. The original entrance is thought to be at the south-west end of the rampart, and it is possible that the fortifications were never finished.

name: Spettisbury Rings
description: Hill / Promonotory fort in Dorset. Overlooking the village of Spettisbury and the floodplain of the Stour valley, with views across to Badbury Rings on the horizon. The central enclosure has a diameter of approx. 150m. Defended by a single rampart and ditch, with a single entrance to the north west. These poor defences suggest that the hillfort was never finished.

name: Flower's Barrow
description: This is a hillfort with a limited future. The south side is falling into the sea at Worbarrow Bay, with perhaps even half of it having already disappeared.

name: Portesham Stone 3
description: This stone lies right next to a footpath which runs from the Hardy Monument to Portesham Hill. It is of typical hard, flinty sarsen and has been incorporated in the construction of a field wall.

name: Portesham Stone Row
description: This is a possible stone row. It is a contiguous line of fallen stones on top of which a field wall has been built. The stones are slabs about 3' square.

name: Portesham Stone 4
description: It stands by the north of the footpath running from the Hardy Monument to Portesham Hill immediately opposite Portesham Stone 10 and near to the possible stone row in the adjacent field.

name: Portesham Stone 10
description:
This Standing Stone in Dorset is a huge block of sarsen measuring over 6' across with a curiously shaped "base", possibly due to weathering. It stands by the south of the footpath running from the Hardy Monument to Portesham Hill immediately opposite Portesham Stone 4.

Is it perhaps a fallen perhaps terminal stone of the Portesham Stone Row running along the edge of the field opposite?

name: Grey Mare Processional Way
description: A Processional Way/Avenue in Dorset. An ancient ridgeway path connected the sites of the Kingston Russell Stone Circle, Grey Mare and her Colts, Hampton Down Stone Circle and the Hellstone Barrow. It runs from SY 578877 near the Kingston Russell Circle, on past the Hellstone Barrow through a stone at SY 609867.

name: Kingston Russell Standing Stone
description: This Standing Stone near Kingston Russell is also known as the Helstone.

name: Corscombe
description: This site, almost certainly the remains of a chambered long barrow, is in a small field on a public footpath running between a minor road just off the north side of the A356 and the village of Corscombe. It lies in a grassy valley with a small wood on the east side and steep sloping fields rising on the west side giving an air of tranquillity and seclusion.

name: Evershot Stones
description: 3 stones, the largest 5' high, incorporated into a bench. These stones are probably the "Three Dumb Sisters" referred to in a field visit made in 1895.

name: Poxwell Cairn
description: Once named "Pokeswell Druid's Temple", Peter Knight, "Ancient Stones of Dorset" believes this to be the remains of a barrow, with natural Sarsen's around the site.

name: Knowlton Great Barrow
description: This is a large tree covered mound near to the Knowlton henges.  There seems to be some debate as to whether this is in fact a burial mound, or some form of viewing area.

name: Broad Stone (Dorset)
description: The Broadstone is to be found flat, almost buried on the verge of the A35 next to the AA layby. It was apparently laid flat to avoid accidents (ie careless drviers hitting it...)

name: Kingston Russell Circle
description: The Kingston Russell stone circle is situated on the flat top of a chalk ridge, overlooking the Bride Valley to the north, and with views westwards to

name: Tenants Hill enclosure
description: There are a collection of earthworks on the promontory north of the Kingston Russell Stone circle, the largest of which is believed to be a Bronze Age enclosure.

name: Devil's Stone (Dorset)
description: The Devils Stone, on the summit of Black Hill near to Bere Regis in Dorset.

name: Nine Barrow Down
description: A Linear Barrow Cemetery of round barrows and a long barrow on the Purbeck ridgeway in Dorset. The long barrow is harder to discern. The barrows are very impressive, and clearly visible for many miles around.

name: Nordon Hill Tumulus
description: A barrow, and once some standing stones, standing on the chalk ridge of Norden Hill, a few hundred metres east of the Dorsetshire Gap.

name: Verwood Stone
description: Stephen's Stone is an ancient block of sandstone found hidden in woodland. It is thought to weigh around 3 tons.

name: Winterbourne Steepleton
description: Remains of a burial chamber; two stones lie halfway up the hillside within farmland on the west side of the road from Hardy Monument to Winterborne Steepleton.

name: Culliford Tree
description: This cemetery of Bronze Age bell-, bowl- and pond barrows extends from the wood, east across the hill top, with a glorious view to the coast, including Chalbury Hill Fort, and the impressive Bincombe Barrows. The eastern members of the group are aligned on and scattered around the neolithic Broadmayne bank barrow.

name: Poor Lot Barrows
description: Barrow Cemetery of bowl, bell, pond and disk barrows in Dorset

name: Ferny Barrows
description: Round Barrows in Dorset. A pair of bowl barrows north of Boat Knoll.

name: Hardy Monument Barrows
description: Barrow Cemetery of around twenty-five barrows in Dorset

name: East Lulworth
description: Barrow Cemetery in Dorset. A linear arrangement of three bowl barrows.

name: Lord's Barrow
description: Round Barrow in Dorset. On the brow of the hill on the road to East Chaldon

name: Five Marys
description: Barrow Cemetery in Dorset. There are actually 7 or 8 round barrows strung out in a line alongside the ridgeway.

name: Pimperne Long Barrow
description: The longest long barrow in Dorset, 106 metres along its axis and 27m wide at its broadest point.

name: Oakley Down Barrows
description: A barrow cemetery of at least 29 barrows in Dorset.

name: Martin's Down Round Barrows
description: Martins Down Bell Barrows are two Bell Barrows adjacent to A35 in Dorset at SY571911. They are 22.9m & 27.4m diameter , and approx. 1.8m high (ref. R.C.H.M. Dorset 1(1952)41.

name: Hod Hill
description: The mighty iron-age ramparts and ditches on Hod Hill enclose an area of 22 hectares, making it the largest hillfort in Dorset. In addition to the earthwork defences, in the southeast corner there are still traces of hut circles and boundaries of the iron-age settlement.

name: Bindon Hill
description: Not much remains of this hillfort earthworks, at the back of Lulworth Cove, but perhaps there never needed to be much, due to the steepness of the hill on the northern side, and the cliffs on the southern side.

name: Abbotsbury Castle
description: Abbotsbury Hillfort in Dorset. A triangular enclosure of 1.8 hectares, with two ramparts separated by single ditch The defences are increased to 4 ramparts and larger ditches at the more vulnerable southeastern end. The bivallate hillfort was developed from a simpler univallate one, and the ramparts appear to have been constructed in a hurry with loads of soil dumped on the banks.
